Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Building and analyzing dynamic brain functional networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Funtional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) offers a rich source of data for understanding brain structure and function. There is an urgent need for computational approaches to eliciting brain structure-function relationships from such data. While current approaches that rely on network representations of fMRI data offer useful insights into brain connectivity, they have significant limitations in terms of discovering and validating complex functional mechanisms that underly brain function: the very notion of a node in the functional network is difficult to define, inter- and intra- subject variability leads to network representations that vary a great deal within and among subjects; and static representations of correlations between activities of different brain regions offer only a partial picture of brain activity which is inherently dynamic.

This exploratory research project aims to introduce dynamic network analysis techniques to discover functional brain regions and study their evolution over time and across subjects. It leverages the research team's experience in the analysis of continuous and highly variable spatio-temporal climate data to address several of the outstanding challenges in analyzing brain networks built from fMRI data. A key goal of this exploratory study is to explore the feasibility of analyzing network representations of fMRI data to answer questions such as the following: Do nodes changes dynamically with time during an fMRI scan? What community detection techniques work best for dynamic networks? What patterns arise in dynamic brain networks? What is the statistical validity of the observed patterns?

Broader Impact: If successful, the project could establish the feasibility of research directions that could eventually lead to computational tools that enable better characterization of normal and abnormal brain function; better understanding of the variation of brain function within and across individuals over time, including patterns that characterize the brain activities of different populations e.g., adolescents, those suffering from specific brain disorders, etc. The project offers enhanced opportunities for interdisciplinary collaborations between neuroscientists and computer scientists, and research-based advanced training of graduate and postdoctoral students at the University of Minnesota. Free dissemination of open source implementations of the algorithms resulting from the project to the larger research community contribute to its broader impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasing availability of Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) data, which record simultaneous brain activity at hundreds of thousands of locations over time, offers great opportunities for studying the principles that govern the normal functioning of the brain and their disruption in the case of mental disorders. The focus of this exploratory project is on leveraging the strength of advanced techniques developed for studying climate science data sets for analyzing brain imaging data that has highly similar characteristics. In addition, we also focused on developing novel algorithms and methods for producing insights pertaining to brain activity in a variety of scenarios, including, when a subject is resting, working on a task, or when the subject has a mental disorder.

The following describes some of the directions we pursued and their results.

Brain Connectivity in Subjects with Schizophrenia Schizophrenia is often characterized as a disease of disconnectivity in the brain. Several studies have been performed to study connectivity differences between healthy subjects and those with schizophrenia using resting state fMRI data in the last two decades. Unfortunately, the regions showing disconnectivity in the disorder are inconsistent across studies. While most of the approaches used in these studies ignored the network connectivity structure, we developed an effective approach to make use of the network structure in order to discover connectivity differences that arise in schizophrenia subjects. We derived multiple insights using our approach: i) subnetworks exhibit connectivity differences, as opposed to individual connections, ii) connectivity of thalamus based subnetworks is found to be reliably different, and iii) quite contrary to conventional wisdom we found that schizophrenia subjects exhibited hyperconnectivity. These findings were in fact supported by independent studies that specifically focused on thalamus connectivity in schizophrenia.

Advances in Studying Brain Connectivity We explored multiple directions in advancing the state of the art in studying brain connectivity from brain imaging data. 

The human brain is known to be a dynamic system where the interactions between different regions are not stationary. Some recent work has explored ways of studying dynamics in brain connectivity at the scale of the entire brain network. In our work, we observed that the dynamics in connectivity arises at a local scale rather than a global scale. We developed algorithms to characterize the dynamics in the connections of the brain and to study these dynamics in resting state and task fMRI data, as well as fMRI data from disease subjects. The dynamics in connectivity discovered using our approach showed promising results for studying fMRI data collected when subjects are resting and fMRI data collected from subjects with schizophrenia. These approaches have utility beyond brain imaging data, for example, in climate science or in analyzing stock market time series data.

Functional neuroanatomy has provided the neuroimaging community with coarse level regions based on the location of sulci (valleys) on the surface of the brain. However, in order to advance our understanding of complex brain related disorders such as Ataxia, the knowledge of fine-level regions in the brain's subcortex is needed. We developed methods for performing a finer level parcellation of the brain by addressing a number of computational and data mining challenges to determine a fine-level brain parcellation. Our results suggested that the finer brain parcellation is highly reliable across multiple brain scans collected from the same subject. These methods have applicability beyond disorders such as Ataxia and can enable the construction of effective brain networks from neuroimaging data.

The objective of studying long-distance relationships has attracted a lot of attention in the climate science community. Several approaches have been developed by us and others to discover tele-connections between two regions (i.e., groups of contiguous locations) that are referred to as dipoles. Recently, we have defined the notion of tripoles, which involve relationships among three regions, where the activity at one region is significantly correlated with the aggregate activity at the other two regions. We observed that tripoles capture novel relationships that are not captured using traditional relationships such as dipoles, and that they reveal novel phenomenon in climate science. As part of this research direction, we studied the existence of tripole relationships in fMRI data. This is a novel contribution and has a potential in significantly changing the way connectivity is currently studied in brain imaging data.

Students: In addition to our technical achievements, this project has contributed to the education of one PhD student as well as thirteen REU students, in the application of data mining, machine learning, and statistical techniques to analyze brain imaging data, particularly fMRI data.
